The Ritenour School District has received $220,863 from the federal E-Rate program this fall that will be used to improve the district’s wireless technology infrastructure and computer network equipment.

E-Rate is a program of the Federal Communications Commission that provides affordable access to communications services to eligible K-12 schools and libraries nationwide. The program helps to ensure that schools and libraries have access to affordable information services and internet access and internet connections. Overall, Ritenour received an 88 percent discount on purchases to bolster its wide area network and for equipment to improve the wireless network in the district.

Missing Girls on the Run this season?

Your Ritenour girl can still participate! Girls on the Run has adapted their program to be delivered virtually. Practices are 45-60 minutes, 2-3 times/week, led by trained and trauma-informed coaches. Lots of physical activity and movement are incorporated into the lessons, which is particularly beneficial during remote learning times. Virtual practices are more than just another Zoom call! Participating on the Ritenour virtual Girls on the Run team on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 4-5 p.m. means your girl can connect with her peers and coaches, stay physically active, and practice really important social and emotional skills to help her stay resilient. This program is here to help support girls during this isolating, challenging time.

Registration for the Ritenour virtual Girls on the Run team can be found at www.gotrstl.org/Fall2020Pgm or by calling 314-862-6266. There are also many other community-wide teams with different practice days/times open for registration!

Yesterday, we were informed by the St. Louis County Department of Public Health that due to the dramatic rise of COVID-19 cases among county residents between 10 and 30 years of age, we must cancel our graduation ceremony planned for Saturday, Aug. 1 in the auditorium.

We did everything possible to organize in-person events to honor our seniors. The class of 2020 has experienced a cascade of disappointments caused by the pandemic. We are heartbroken that we are not able to celebrate our 340 graduates in-person. More details about how the class of 2020 will receive their diplomas will be shared at a later date.

We are so proud of what our students have accomplished, and we ask you to join us in congratulating the class of 2020. Please show your support for our amazing graduates, who would welcome positive well wishes as they navigate the hurdles of the pandemic that have disrupted so many of their plans. Our Huskies have always shown a tremendous amount of fortitude and resiliency, and we know they have a bright future ahead.

The Ritenour School District has expanded its technology to ensure that all of its K-12 students will have a computer device at the beginning of the 2020-2021 school year. Additionally, it is increasing WiFi access for students who do not have access to the internet in their homes.

Ritenour buses equipped with WiFi hotspots are parked this summer at all Ritenour school campuses, providing students WiFi access when they are within 150 feet of the buses. Students can easily tap into the bus WiFi to participate in online learning and complete assignments if they cannot access it from home.

Students will receive devices at the start of the 2020-2021 school year. More information about the device rollouts will be shared with families, including training sessions for families and students, closer to the first day of school, which is Monday, Aug. 24.

Learn more at tinyurl.com/ritenour1-1

Did you know? Ritenour has nearly one million square feet of school facilities with a replacement value of more than $300 million. The average age of a Ritenour school is 50 years old! These buildings are safe and well-constructed, but require extensive ongoing maintenance, repair and renovation just like our homes.

Prop S - a zero tax rate change bond issue on the Tuesday, June 2 ballot - will help Ritenour do the facility work necessary to keep our buildings safe and cost efficient to adequately meet the learning needs of our students today and in the future.

Everyone in Ritenour continues to work hard for our students during recent changes as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. We must also continue to plan for the future for our students and families. These improvements are needed to keep our buildings in good working condition and protect our commitment to providing outstanding schools for our children both now and in the future.

Others shared projects on elements of African American culture that were important to them like hair products, justice and freedom.

post_text: Congratulations to Dr. Stacey Albin-Wilson, vice president of the Ritenour Board of Education, for attaining master certification in the Missouri School Boards’ Association (MSBA) certified board member program. To earn this level of certification, Dr. Albin-Wilson completed additional professional development requirements beyond the 16 hours required by the Outstanding Schools Act of 1993. She earned at least 24 additional training credits, read two books related to school board service, attended at least two MSBA events and wrote an essay on her board service. Board Director Dr. Brad Thomas also has a master certification, which he earned in 2002. #RitenourExcellence

Ritenour High School hosted its third annual military career fair today. Nearly 100 RHS seniors who have expressed an interest in military service met with representatives from eight different branches – including the Air Force, Air National Guard, Army, Army National Guard, Army Reserve, Coast Guard, Marines and Navy.

In addition to the military fair, RHS hosts many opportunities for students to explore options for their future – including college fairs, job fairs and a construction trades expo. The goal is to give students an expanded view of all options available to them as they prepare to graduate from high school.

Can't make it to RHS for the showing of the Ritenour documentary "College Bound" at the strategic planning meeting Nov. 5? Join the conversation in the live Facebook premiere!

“College Bound,” a documentary produced by the Ritenour Community Services Department, is a 50-minute film that features Ritenour students and families as they overcome poverty, culture and language barriers, fear and other obstacles to be accepted into top universities in the country. Their journey proves that anything is possible with hard work, long hours, and a college counselor who knows the secrets to breaking through the confines of America's system of higher education.
